title: Monday, 26th June, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Morning, welcome to Markets Live

PM11:01am

Holland & Barrett maybe?

PM11:01am

Yeah, they're not listed

11:01 am
PM11:02am

But I'm intrigued that a Russian oligarch would want to buy this

PM11:02am

When basically all these shops do is sell nonsense

PM11:02am

11:02 am
PM11:03am

A pleasant and easy way to add valuable bulk to your diet.

PM11:03am

14 quid a bottle

PM11:03am

As psyllium husks pass through the body they turn into a gel which expands considerably, supporting the collection of waste products through the intestines.

11:03 am
BE11:04am

Yep. It's in the grey area of drugs legislation where you can sell anything that doesn't explicitly kill you as a health product.

PM11:04am

Even if some of these potions do work, H&B prices them in such a comic way

BE11:04am

And they don't work, mostly.

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Course they don't

PM11:04am

Anyway, good luck Mikhail Fridman

BE11:05am

I've been intrigued, since you mention it, about H&B's expansion strategy.

11:05 am
PM11:05am

Go on

PM11:06am

Here's Friedman btw (man who foxed BP)

PM11:06am

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Seems to have opened a spectacular number of shops over the past couple of years, in areas you wouldn't expect vitamin hokum and ragwort-for-your-biliousness stuff to sell that well.

BE11:06am

I can't imagine many of them make a turn.

BE11:06am

I can't imagine many of them will survive past the next lease renewal.

11:06 am
PM11:07am

Yeah, the shops are largely empty -- and just rely and bogof deals and the like

BE11:07am

And on that basis I'd be interested to see how much work Friedman has put into LFL and how much on sales growth.

BE11:08am

A retail business is quite easy to fluff up for a buyer not paying close attention. Look at Game, for instance.

11:08 am
PM11:08am

This is true

BE11:08am

The trick's been pulled there about four times.

BE11:08am

Anyway, good luck both to Mr F and to H&B's customers. They both need it.

11:08 am
undefined
PM11:09am

So sterling down, cos the dollar's rebounded, which means the Footsie's up as well!

PM11:09am

50 points or so

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Hooray! Oil, mostly, I think.

BP PLC (BP.:LSE): Last: 458.70, up 2.35 (+0.51%), High: 460.40, Low: 457.60, Volume: 4.03m
BE11:10am

(Is that today's price?)

11:10 am
Royal Dutch Shell PLC (RDSB:LSE): Last: 2,107, up 10.5 (+0.50%), High: 2,119, Low: 2,105, Volume: 1.14m
BE11:10am

And mining.

BHP Billiton PLC (BLT:LSE): Last: 1,154, up 11 (+0.96%), High: 1,158, Low: 1,145, Volume: 995.58k
11:10 am
Rio Tinto PLC (RIO:LSE): Last: 3,079, up 26.5 (+0.87%), High: 3,085, Low: 3,060, Volume: 644.10k
PM11:10am

Yes, those prices are current (ish)

Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 282.27, up 2.77 (+0.99%), High: 283.70, Low: 280.05, Volume: 16.61m
11:10 am
BE11:11am

Below that, it's a bit quiet.

PM11:11am

Some people seem to be trying to pin this on the Italian bank bailout and/or German IFO figures

PM11:11am

And the MIB in Italy is up 1.4%

11:11 am
PM11:11am

Have you looked at the Italian stuff?

BE11:12am

(@Vixal: trick with the high SKU count is that they're all exceptionally long life.)

BE11:12am

Can't say I have.

11:12 am
PM11:12am

I don't know how they've managed it

PM11:12am

I thought there were supposed to be ECB rules around bailouts now

PM11:13am

But the Italians have just dodged 'em all

11:13 am
PM11:13am

Euro statement here https://srb.europa.eu/en/node/341

PM11:13am

As for the Italian solution, I can just get Deutsche to explain

PM11:13am

A recap of the weekend events1)On Fridaythe ECBdeclaredBP Vicenza (BVPI)and Veneto Banca (VB)failing or likely to fail, as they repeatedlybreachedsupervisory capital requirements.2)The ECB informed the Single Resolution Board, which concluded that the conditions for a resolution action had not been met. HenceBPVI and VBhadtobe wound up under Italian insolvency. https://srb.europa.eu/en/node/3413)On Sunday the Italian government issued a decree ruling the liquidation of BPVI and VB.The decreealso defined the overall costs of theintervention.4)DG comp confirmed that this plan does not breach European state aid rules

11:13 am
PM11:14am

How the liquidation will work1)A bad bank will be formed with BPVI and VB’sNPLs; their subordinated bonds will be transferred there. The rest of their assets and liabilities will be part of the good bank perimeter(details below).2)BPVI and VB former equity / subordinated bonds will cover the costs of NPL clean-up in the bad bank. The rest of the banking systemwill reimburse the 80% to the retail subordinated bond holders (E200mapprox.), ISP will add the other 20% -E60m(on top of itspro-quota of the 80%).3)ISP will buy the good bank for the symbolic price of E1 and receive a public contribution of E3.5bn, to be recorded as revenue in P&L(not subject to tax). E1.285bn will be added to cover for restructuring coststo close 600 branches and reduce the staff by 3.9k units(again booked in P&L and not subject to tax).4)The government has also defined up to E12bn of guarantees, related to: a) litigation, up to E1.991bn, b) assets retrocession by ISP in the next three years (E4bn risky assets)c) E6bn to cover the credit line that ISP provides to the bad bank(market rate), to cover the gap between its assets and liabilities.

PM11:14am

Got that? I think Italian tax payers get a bill for 17bn euros

PM11:14am

And Intesa get's the good assets

11:14 am
PM11:15am

Impacts for Intesa –positive deal,in line with our scenarioIn our note published on 23-Jun-27, we show the potential impacts for ISP on capital (neutral) and EPS (a minimum of 5-7% 2019E EPS accretion). Most of thenote assumptions are consistent with the decisionstaken during the weekend.http://pull.db-gmr...8c08d2131fe.pdf.In our view the deal is positive for ISP at theseconditions; managerial time/effort will be necessary, but most of the keyexecutionrisks are covered (also: if the decree is not passed intodefinitivelaw, ISP’soffer is not valid anymore).

PM11:15am

How the good bank looks likeThe good bank includes: a)E26bn performing loans, b)E4bn risky loans which ISP can transfer backinto the bad bank if they become NPLs by 2020, c)financial assets of around E8.9bn, d)senior bonds of around E11.8bn, e)deposits for E25.8bn, f)indirect funding of E23bn (o/w E10.4bn AUM), g)900 branches in Italy and around 60 abroad including the bank network in Romania, around 9,960 people in Italy and around 880 abroad. Importantly, ISP will also obtained tax assets of E1.9bn (we expected E1.2bn)

PM11:15am

That will do on that

11:15 am
PM11:16am

Intesa San Paolo a the top of the euro leaderboard

BE11:16am

Okay, so Italy's wearing it to protect senior bondholders and depositors, as well as by extension the other banks?

PM11:16am

UP 4%

11:16 am
BE11:16am

And Intesa gets to cherry pick what it wants from the corpse?

BE11:16am

(Don't think you can cherry pick from a corpse. You know what I mean.)

PM11:18am

As for Italian debt dynamics

11:17 am
PM11:18am

Credit Suisse determined to see the bright side...

PM11:18am

Meanwhile, the economic and financial backdrop is better than generally depicted.This should avoid more dramatic and systemic concerns around Italy and the euro area, from both a political and a market viewpoint. Debt sustainability dynamics are, if anything, favourable and leading to a debt reductionin the coming years, in most scenarios, as we show in this note

PM11:18am

We also show that there is little to fear from ECB’s expected QE tapering next year.While interest rates might well increase as a consequence, we believe the positive impact of ECB’s QE will persistent long after 2018.

11:18 am
PM11:18am

Defaulting... but on whom?Italy’s public debt is largely held domestically;the International Investment Positionof the countryis only slightly negative. A default would correspond to a massive internal redistribution of wealth, accompanied by wealth destruction–and a significantloss of credibility... Not even Greece went for aunilateral debt repudiation: we see no rationale to expect itin Italy. Clearly, though, in Italy like elsewhere, there isrising political support for more redistributivepolicies, against austerity.That should be factored in inmarket participants’ projections, we believe.

PM11:19am

That's enough Italy for a monday morning

undefined
11:19 am
BE11:19am

Someone on the right is badgering for HSBC on Shell ........

BE11:19am

......... it's kinda dull, but that's never stopped us before. So:

BE11:20am

In this report we examine Shell’s financial outlook (including in a lower-for-longer crude price scenario) as well as its medium-term growth prospects. Our unchanged Buy rating on Shell’s A and B shares relate to our view that we’ll see significant progress in de-risking the balance sheet in the next 1-2 years. However, we are less convinced of the company’s operational competitive advantages vs the other supermajor peers on a longer term view.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Even though we don’t expect 1Q17’s USD10.5bn of underlying cash flow to be repeated this year, we still see cash flow growth of 57% y/y. This should be sufficient to cover cash capex and the dividend - albeit with the scrip dividend. Shell is also making significant progress in its disposals programme and we expect proceeds to aid balance sheet gearing to be down below 24% by end-2017.

BE11:21am

We see underlying volume growth of c.7% in 2017 from BG’s Brazil assets and other Shell legacy projects, although headline volumes could only be flat after disposals. Post-2017 we see limited volume growth through 2020, with 2016-20 underlying growth the weakest of the supermajors except Exxon. We believe the 2020-25 outlook in the upstream is only around average at best.

BE11:21am

Thanks to share issuance for the BG transaction, Shell’s dividend burden of over USD15bn pa represents the sector’s highest payout
as a proportion of our 2018-20 cash flow and free cash estimates. This is not necessarily an issue at higher crude prices - and our base case crude price assumptions point to the flexibility for Shell to start making inroads into offsetting some of the share issuance. However, the disposals programme will only bring
temporary relief in the event of lower-for-longer crude prices. In such a scenario the dividend still look sustainable, but the margins for error look fairly meagre.

11:21 am
BE11:22am

So ... buy BP. But buy Shell as well, just not so much.

BE11:22am

We think Exxon’s c45% average valuation premium vs
Shell on 2018-19e EV/DACF is unjustified, and expect this gap to close over time. However, we also don’t believe Shell should be trading at corresponding premiums to BP (BP LN, 457p, Buy) and Total (FP FP, EUR44.35, Buy) of 12% and 14% respectively. More specifically, we think the risk/reward balance is more attractive in BP than in Shell. BP has less near-term financial flexibility than Shell by virtue of its Deepwater Horizon outlays vs Shell’s disposals proceeds. However, we think BP has better upstream growth and upstream asset strength-in-depth post-2020, as well as more visible growth opportunities in its downstream businesses.

BE11:22am

There. That's that.

11:22 am
undefined
BE11:22am

To movers? There ain't much around.

PM11:23am

Sure

11:23 am
PM11:23am

Someone downgraded William Hill?

BE11:23am

Some forecast downgrades.

BE11:23am

Numis and Stifel.

11:23 am
BE11:24am

This is partly on Australia banning -- or about to ban, to be more accurate -- betting on credit.

BE11:24am

Which is a reasonable sized bit of William Hill's business.

PM11:25am

Wasnt aware of that

11:25 am
BE11:25am

I wrote a bit about it on Friday but the shares barely moved then and analysts insisted it was a known known, so I cut it for space. Ah well.

William Hill PLC (WMH:LSE): Last: 264.40, down 10.1 (-3.68%), High: 275.10, Low: 264.20, Volume: 1.29m
BE11:26am

So this is the Interactive Gambling Amendment Bill, banning online and offline bookies from providing credit to people in Australia, regardless of country of origin.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Circa 20 - 30% of Net Revenue at William Hill’s Australian
business is from credit.

PM11:26am

goodness

BE11:27am

(Paddy Power and Ladbrokes say their exposure's minimal and irrelevant.)

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Bill has cross-party support and should become law in August, when the Oz parliament comes back from the beach.

BE11:28am

Anyway, that's prompted several brokers to take forecasts back. Stifel first.

BE11:28am

Which also cites poor football results. I'll have my now traditional rant about that in a moment.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Poor sporting results have continued into Q2; proposed credit ban in Australia is problematic While there is confidence that the business is in much stronger health than a year ago with good momentum in Online, poor sporting results have continued into Q2 and there are negative developments in Australia. Accordingly we downgrade our estimates.

BE11:28am

Retail (55% of EBIT): The UK Retail business is robust and is gaining market share, although disappointing sporting results have continued into Q2 and it is perhaps unrealistic to expect the shortfall to be recovered in H2. On the triennial review of stakes and prizes for machines, we consider the political situation is not conducive to an early decision and may prolong the timetable beyond October. We remain of the view that reducing the stake level is a blunt policy instrument which, in isolation, may not address the issue of problem gambling and that little attention has focused on the obvious fact that problem gamblers can shift their play to other forms of gambling (see our note of 26 April). While uncertainty exists, we regard an extreme reduction in the B2 stake level to £2 as highly unlikely.

BE11:29am

Online (34% of EBIT): There is confidence on the turnaround in Online as evidenced by the 9% stake growth in the first 17 weeks and the business appears to have regained momentum, although recent sporting results have been poor.

11:28 am
BE11:29am

Australia (5% of EBIT): While the sportsbetting market is growing at 15%pa, the business faces familiar headwinds in terms of competition, regulation and
taxation. Please see our note of 16 June following a meeting with Tom Waterhouse, CEO of William Hill Australia. Last week the Australian government announced it would legislate to ban credit betting, which represents 30% of group revenues and 25% of gross profit. Assuming the legislation proceeds this could impact profits by around £17m next year. In addition there is a significant risk of tax increases, which may prompt consolidation in the market.

BE11:29am

(@Mr Diamond: isn't that a legacy of the Playtech relationship so not entirely unexpected?)

BE11:29am

US (5% of EBIT): With a 26% share of retail sports betting in Nevada, William Hill US has achieved good growth in recent years. This gives it some optionality on regulatory change in sportsbetting in the medium term.

Downgrading forecasts: We downgrade our EBIT and PBT forecast by £17m for 2017 due to poor sporting results and higher than expected central costs.
For 2018 we downgrade our EBIT and PBT forecasts by £16m largely reflecting the likely ban on Credit Betting in Australia. At the interim stage we expect EBIT of £120m, down £11m, and PBT of £100m, down £9m.

11:29 am
BE11:30am

Valuation: While progress is being made on the turnaround of Online, poor sporting results have continued into Q2 and developments in Australia are concerning. While the downgrade to estimates is disappointing, the shares remain fundamentally overshadowed by the machine review.

BE11:30am

And Numis. Same deal.

BE11:30am

Sporting results and regulation have not been kind to William Hill in recent months. A poor end to the 1H football season will weigh on GW margins with no guarantee it will be recovered in 2H. Coupled with additional central costs, we are therefore cutting our FY17 EBIT by £29m (10%) to £251m, which is 8% below consensus. Furthermore, there are already headwinds building for FY18; as well as new likely rules on FOBT stakes, the CMA is focusing on on-line practises, and Australia has proposed the banning of credit betting (c.30% of amounts wagered). We therefore remain cautious, cutting our TP to 277p to reflect the lower earnings outlook.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

● Cutting FY17 EBIT by 10% to £251m. Customer-friendly football results in May and June have impacted gross win margins across its retail (-£8m impact on FY EBIT)
and online (-£5m) divisions. In addition, Australian margins are under pressure from a structural shift in product and customer mix (-£7m). Assuming a normalised margin in 2H as well as raising our forecast for central costs and contribution from associates (-£8m), we are cutting our FY EBIT forecast by £29m (10%) to £251m, which is 8% below consensus.

BE11:30am

● Interims will look soft: WMH will report interim results on 3 August. Given the soft GW margin coupled with higher marketing costs and central costs, we forecast 1H17
EBIT of £131m (-7% yoy). Divisionally, we only see progress from online, with top line growth offsetting the headwinds

BE11:30am

● More headwinds expected in FY18. Notwithstanding the likely impact from the review on FOBT staking, the CMA is launching enforcement against industry members due to terms of sign-up bonuses. Additionally, the prohibition of credit betting in Australia will, as feared, include existing credit accounts, equivalent to c.30% of amounts staked. Together with higher central costs, we are cutting FY18 EBIT by 7%.

11:30 am
BE11:31am

● Remaining cautious. Despite some good underlying progress being made internally (amounts staked online +9% yoy, retail +2% yoy and Australia +53% yoy for year to
25 April) external headwinds from sporting results and regulation continue to impact earnings, many of which will also impact Ladbrokes Coral. In our view, geographic
diversification is the only long-term solution for a more robust earnings profile. We are cutting our sum of parts based target price to 277p (see overleaf). In the light of likely downgrades, we retain our cautious HOLD recommendation.

BE11:31am

Okaaaaaaaaaaaaaay .............

PM11:31am

??

11:31 am
BE11:31am

So, "unfavourable sporting results" .............

BE11:31am

Here's the thing: if you wait long enough, gross win margin should be constant.

BE11:31am

It might fluctuate, quarter to quarter or even year to year, because that's what happens in games of chance. But saying there's "no guarantee [gross win margins] will be recovered in H2" seems to be the opposite of how gambling works. The house always wins.

11:31 am
BE11:32am

As in, this:

BE11:32am

PM11:32am

hehehe

11:32 am
BE11:32am

If the long-term gross win doesn't average back to a fairly pedestrian but steady margin then either the bookmaker itself is punting, or it's deliberately taking down its margin for promotional reasons or whatever, and blaming chance.

PM11:32am

Im with you on this

BE11:32am

Okay, a quarter or a half might be bad, but investors are not prepared to see through that? That's not how investors work.

11:01 am
PM11:01am

Wondering what to kick off with.

BE11:34am

Unless we're saying "poor sporting results" is a lie. In which case, perhaps don't invest in companies that lie.

BE11:34am

(Awaits emails.)

UKOG mentioned on the right

11:36 am
PM11:36am

UK Oil & Gas announced on Friday at 11:59 that mobile light oil has been observed seeping from open natural fractures in the Kimmeridge Limestone 4 (“KL4”) core samples from the 100% held Broadford Bridge-1 (“BB-1”) well. We increase our TP to 2.83p (2.33p) to reflect the derisked nature of this well. This morning, the company provided a further update providing data suggesting that the shales, in addition to the limestones, may contribute to the scale and productivity of the resource, we have not factored this potential into our valuation.

PM11:38am

11:40 am
undefined
BE11:40am

Back to stuff then.

BE11:40am

And Capita's disposal was mentioned earlier.

11:40 am
Capita PLC (CPI:LSE): Last: 710.00, up 18.5 (+2.68%), High: 721.00, Low: 691.50, Volume: 2.42m
BE11:40am

Price a bit better than rumoured.

BE11:41am

And more importantly, the agreement of a deal probably gives Capita enough breathing space with lenders heading into the next covenant test.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Course, it's had to sell one of its best and most consistently profitable businesses just to survive. But needs must.

BE11:42am

Here's Barclays to say it's already in the price post last week's rally.

BE11:42am

On Friday, Capita announced the sale of its Asset Services business to Link Group (an Australian provider of pension fund admin services) for £888m (on a cash & debt free basis). With FY17 EBITA of ~£60m this implies a multiple of c15x. Closest peer, Equiniti trades on c13.9x FY17e EV/EBITA (14.5x ‘16A) by comparison.

Net cash proceeds from the transaction are expected to be c£816m, after transaction and other expenses of £72m, of which a one-off pension contribution represents £17m and separation costs c£15m. Including the previously announced sale of its specialist recruitment business (announced at the trading update) for an estimated £10-15m (under £25m), total net proceeds from disposals this year are around £830m, compared to the £800m we previously modeled – so marginally better than expected.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Pro-forma Net debt/ EBITDA is said to have been 1.8x at YE-16 (vs. the 2.9x reported). We model 1.6x leverage by the end of FY17e. £134m of the disposal proceeds will likely be used to pay down the groups receivables financing facility, with the remainder paying down short term debt (although some cash may be held back to pay off some private placement debt maturing next year).

The sale is subject to regulatory approval and is expected to complete in Q4 2017. The impact on the P&L this year (in terms of interest costs) is therefore limited (management guidance remains £70-75m). For next year, the pay down of the receivables financing facility adds a couple of million to operating profit (the facility was fairly low cost and taken through the operating profit line), and the interest charge expected to benefit to the tune of c£10m – reducing interest costs to c£60m – we currently forecast c£64m.

BE11:42am

Capita’s recent trading update (13th June) trading was said to be in line with expectations, with 1H17 profits expected to be no lower than that reported in 2H16. This includes an undisclosed benefit from the early adoption of IFRS 15 and was better than their previous expectation of a decline yoy. Profitability is still expected to improve in 2H. Company collected consensus adj. EBITA expectations for 2017 remain at c£495m (Barclays £490m). For 2018e, company collected adj. PTP expectations are c£450m (c5% ahead of our £427m forecast).

BE11:43am

Major contracts - The MoD is reviewing Capita’s DIO contract (worth £60m p.a.); this is at risk of shrinkage this year and possible early termination & retendering in June 2019. Capita is also flagging higher resourcing costs in the PGSE (NHS) contract (factored into 1H guidance).

Share price reflects a return to normality

The shares have risen c25% since the trading update on 13th June, and now trade on c14x FY18e PE (post-disposal), c12x EBITA, with a 6.5% FCF yield.

Whilst a good price for CAS and near term trading profit certainty are welcome positives, we remain concerned that Capita is not out of the woods completely, as we don’t yet have a CEO, further contract reviews cannot be ruled out, the pipeline is still very weak (compounded now by UK political uncertainty). We also see scope for cost savings as likely re-invested as the group turns away from acquisition-led growth to a more organic future (no easy task, in our view).

11:43 am

PM11:43am

We provide the infrastructure, services and expertise through which assets are secured or deployed

11:51 am

BE11:52am

BE11:52am

11:52 am
BE11:52am

BE11:53am

BE11:53am

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Analysts saying, "big ask".

PM11:53am

He'll be feeling the pressure

BE11:53am

Here's Jefferies.

11:53 am
PM11:53am

Schneider, that is

BE11:54am

Third Point scope 2020 EPS under their plan of between CHF
5.00 & 6.00, relative to underlying EPS of CHF 3.40 in FY16A and a current FY20 consensus per FactSet of CHF 4.35 (which reflects a 16.9% underlying margin). Third Point's numbers stack up for us on a purely mechanical basis. We think FY20 consensus would be in excess of CHF 6.00 were it to cumulate fully all four elements.

BE11:54am

There has been much speculation about the margin opportunity at NESN ahead of an investor seminar 26 September. Schneider said in February that NESN had 'heard the message' on margins, but recent mood music has been more cautious, in the face of bullish broker opinion. We observe that current gross cost savings (Continuous Excellence and Structural) promise an incremental 800bps or so by 2020. Achieving Third Point's target would, therefore, require a retention rate of c.50%, relative to c.15% historically. ULVR's plan assumes a c.33% rate.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

We concur with Third Point on the OR stake. But disposing
of it totally will not be straightforward, governed as it is by a co-ordination agreement with the Bettencourt family (who own 33% of OR) that embraces mutual pre-emption rights. There may also be tax implications.

BE11:55am

Outside Third Point's normal envelope. Third Point have a track record of taking 5-10% stakes in companies such as Sony, Baxter International, Sotheby's Yahoo and Massey Energy. Their model is to argue for change, often seeking board representation and/or board change. Disclosure of their involvement has added between 3% and 10% to target's share prices, based on a brief review. We note that the NESN stake is well to the low end of Third Point's normal range

BE11:55am

Don't expect a roll-over. So another chapter opens in the ongoing culture wars around how to unlock value from staples businesses, in today's low-growth world. Bulls will cite recent ULVR experience. However, we note that ULVR were i.) were fighting for their lives in the face of a takeover bid and ii.) had already scoped and published an accelerated savings plan. While we think NESN are serious about accelerating margins and returns, we view them as a proud company with an enduring model. We expect them to be wary of bending too readily, too publicly, to the views of an ultimately small shareholder

11:55 am
BE11:56am

All this can be connected back to 3G lighting a fire under the sector, of course.

PM11:56am

Indeed

BE11:56am

Here's UBS as well.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

In our in-depth launch report (link) we argued Nestlé could unlock value from (1) cost cutting: Nestlé's profitability lags global peers despite its scale. Moving from our base case of +35bps pa EBIT margin uplift in 2018-20 to +80bps pa (to 19% by 2020 vs Unilever's target for 20%) would increase our 2020E EPS by +8%; (2) balance sheet deployment: Nestlé's 0.7x 2017E ND/EBITDA (or 0.7x net cash incl. L'Oreal stake) and CHF10bn FCF leaves room for buybacks & M&A, in our view. Assuming Nestlé levers up to just 1.5x ND/EBITDA via buybacks would add +6% to our EPS; and (3) portfolio management: in January we argued that US Confectionery was not a good fit (it is now under a strategic review, link). We question the fit of the Confectionery division overall (10% of 2016 sales) to Nestlé's Nutrition, Health & Wellness strategy. At industry transaction multiples of 13-17x EV/EBITDA, this business could be worth CHF20-26bn.

BE11:58am

Could this news increase pressure on Danone?
We think yes. Danone has underperformed peers in recent years as its earnings momentum has fallen short of expectations. However, we do not see any 'easy' fixes to Danone's problems: Dairy continues to be difficult with shifting consumer tastes, and WWAV will take some time to stabilise in the US. We think Nestlé is in a better starting position with strong positions in a majority of its portfolio (e.g. coffee, pet, waters, nutrition).

BE11:58am

That's an interesting line right there.

11:58 am
PM11:58am

On Danone?

BE11:59am

Yep. Will be unsurprised to see quite a bit of noise around Danone on the back of this.

BE11:59am

Nestlé trades on 21.6x 18E PE, a 5% premium to EU Staples (long-term range: 0-10% premium). UBS analysis (link) suggests that the stock continues to be the 3rd most underweighted stock in Developed Europe. With cautious buyside expectations, we see upside potential from earnings upgrades in the next 12m – Reiterate Buy. Our PT of CHF84 based primarily on a DCF, assuming a WACC of 7.7% and a terminal FCF growth assumption of 2.5%
